storyInfo: In a dilapidated inn, a writer tells a fragmented tale: the greedy red dragon rouses the long-dead Exiled King, while her noble sister leads her companions back to the capital of Tara, Na Saoirsí.

attributes.text: To reclaim her kingdom from the foes, the red dragon of greed sought the aid of a shadowy force, the dark mist that haunted in the forest.

The red dragon breathed the fire of death, while the dark mist herded their foes into the blazing flames. Thus, the battle was won and the kingdom was hers. The thorn-choked fields began to stir with life once again.
Yet the deadly fire still crept across the land. The fields withered; the living faltered. The newborn perished before they could bloom, while the passing lingered, bound to this land.

The red dragon would not abide the death going unrestrained. Her wish was firm: life to life, death to death. Resolute in her purpose, she sought to cease the spreading fire. As Samhain drew near, she gathered those touched by the tainted flames into her lair.

attributes.content: ...And that is the story of the red dragon.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: But what comes after? What about the people tainted by the flames of death?
There is no 'after'. That's all I've written.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: That simply will not do.
Everything has an ending, and those endings don't much care if you think they'll do, miss.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: And yet it is for an altogether different reason that you hide yourself in this dilapidated pub after publishing your work. How ridiculous.
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: A lot of things are ridiculous.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: Do you simply enjoy keeping people in suspense? Is your spirit soothed by tales of readers desperate to know the ending?
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: Some overly enthusiastic Messengers did manage to find me to deliver some fan mail.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: You must have been rather pleased.
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: Pleased? I didn't even read them. Just tossed them into that fireplace.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: How impertinent.
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: Moreover, not a single story in your collection doesn't cut off unceremoniously. Truly impertinent.
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: It's simple, really. I can't write an ending to save my life.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: You'd best head home now, miss. You're clearly well-educated, and a ramshackle pub like this doesn't suit you. Don't fret yourself over those half-finished stories.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: Why the hurry to show me the door? Perhaps I can help you.
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: The author takes measure of the woman once more. Even with a hood over her head, he can see how pale her face is. She must be very sickly, he thinks.
The moment she arrived in this abandoned village, she went straight for the pub. She had clearly done her research, and seems unlikely to give up anytime soon.
After ruminating, he picks up a sticky mug left among the cards and chips strewn across the table and downs a mouthful of rancid beer.
Alright then. So what kind of ending were you thinking?
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: Why should I be the one to come up with it?
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: You're the writer, not me. I simply wished to offer my own story, to spark your imagination.
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: Your own story?
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: Wait, are you another survivor? Did you also narrowly escape death in that city last autumn?
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: Only those who've experienced the truth for themselves would recognize what your stories are based on.
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: Well, go ahead then. I'm all ears.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: Very well. Deep in the ruins of the former royal capital of Tara, long since destroyed by Catastrophe...
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: Deep in the ruins of the former royal capital of Tara, long since destroyed by Catastrophe, on one uneventful yet peaceful day, the flame burning in a metal stove was snuffed out.
This was no urgent matter, but the red dragon came all the same.
Does it resist being lit?
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: Or is it that not even an ominous outsider—newly come after centuries of silence—can relight old longings and resentments, near worn away by time?
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: Or... perhaps I simply need to be less reserved.
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: A purple flame dances around the stove.
Under its light, the red dragon's face looks even paler than before.
Are you awake?
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: Or must I remind you who you are?
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: The pathetic red dragon who cast aside his crown and wandered the wilderness for twenty years, only to be murdered by his closest kin on his return. Labhréathach the Exiled King, correct?
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: It truly is a pity, seeing someone still in shock at his own bloody death, six hundred years after the fact.
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: Six hundred years?
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: Give or take. The true date of your death has long been forgotten.
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: I'm shocked, yes, but not at my death. More at the fact that, after six hundred years, the Dracos have once again produced an aberration spewing the flames of death.
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: They even let you grow to adulthood without strangling you in the crib.
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: Did the Victorians bid you rouse me from death's slumber? Or did you hide that ridiculous crown from them beneath your bed?
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: Victoria no longer yokes the Red Dragon. The Tara of today heeds no foreign master.
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: Hah, not bad.
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: Tell me then, is it popular to wake the dead to deliver good news these days? But sorry, but I've nothing to reward you with. Now if that's all, you'd best be on your way.
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: With my flames burning within you, you won't be ending this after a few trifling pleasantries, Labhréathach.
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: Ending? My ending came long, long ago. You're the one with unfinished business, yeah?
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: Look, I get it. They're the flames of death, after all. They'll get you into all kinds of trouble. Life and death getting jumbled up, herds of undying beasts, newborn cubs having their lives snuffed out before you know it, the works.
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: So, how big a mess are we talking here? A field? A city? A countryside?
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: I set all of Tara alight to free her from Victoria's heel.
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: You WHAT?!
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: Let her be razed to the ground. Let Tara become a nation of the dead. Either way, the flames of death will seek out new kindling. Or so I thought, at first.
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: But allowing so many lives to fade away simply because I am out of ideas, well, that would be awfully imprudent of me.
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: And so I came to you. Tell me, what should I do to cleanse these deathly flames from the fields of Tara?
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: ...If only that were empty bluster.
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: Go ahead, use your imagination.
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: I've heard enough. What I'm about to say isn't for you, but for all the people still willing to call themselves Tarans.
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: Those tainted by your flame and marching towards death have been renounced by life itself. It will never return to them.
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: This goes without saying for the corpses marching behind you, obviously, but the same holds for those who still live yet walk like the dead. There's no medicine that can save them.
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: Gather them together, so that their fires do not taint others.
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: Appeasement. Is that all you can suggest?
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: Hah... Of course not.
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: Next, find another red dragon. Assuming you haven't already slaughtered your kin, of course.
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: Find a real red dragon, one whose flames warm others' lives. Let things return to as they once were. Ashes to ashes, dust to dust, life to life, death to death.
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: Is that all you know?
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: It is, ignorant young dragon.
attributes.name: The Exiled King

attributes.content: Then it seems you don't know much more than I do.
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: The red dragon does not even bother to sneer at him. She simply turns and leaves.
She passes by a ruined home, faint yellow candlelight seeping through the cracks.
This is the wilderness where the dead roam. No one should be living here. And so, she knocks on the door.
Who're you?
attributes.name: Decrepit Old Man

attributes.content: Who I am is unimportant. What's important is, why are you living out here?
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: I came because there aren't any Victorians here to knock at my door and rob the food I dug up myself, along with my savings...
attributes.name: Decrepit Old Man

attributes.content: Five years ago, on a night like this, a wicked caster came by, killing the Victorians as they closed in, step by step.
attributes.name: Decrepit Old Man

attributes.content: I offered him beastmeat, grains, and freshly-brewed wine, but he told me he didn't need any of it. What he needed was fire, a fire fueled by those who would happily burn themselves away.
attributes.name: Decrepit Old Man

attributes.content: And so my only son, Keith, left home and followed him.
attributes.name: Decrepit Old Man

attributes.content: What a noble soul.
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: Then, three years ago, someone knocked on my door in the middle of the night again. It was Keith.
attributes.name: Decrepit Old Man

attributes.content: My Keith. He no longer spoke, or wept, or even breathed. He just stood there, his body covered in purple flames.
attributes.name: Decrepit Old Man

attributes.content: How tragic.
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: It gets worse. I buried him, but he refused to rot away in the earth. Instead, he dug himself out, and now his corpse is wandering endlessly the wilds.
attributes.name: Decrepit Old Man

attributes.content: Which is why I'm still living here.
attributes.name: Decrepit Old Man

attributes.content: Are you one of that caster's friends? Are you here to lay Keith to rest?
attributes.name: Decrepit Old Man

attributes.content: I am.
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: Ah, here he comes.
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: A walking corpse, wreathed in purple flame for all to see, shambles towards the two.
The red dragon presses the point of her spear against the corpse's chest. The fire rages so hot that it sears away its flesh in an instant, leaving nothing more than ash.
But an idle thought crosses the old man's mind: the fire did not seem to burn out, but instead went up along the spear to return to the red dragon's body.
And what of you? You're also tainted by the purple flames of death, are you not?
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: The old man looks himself over, but sees no flames licking his body like they did with his only son. But to the dragon, the flame consuming him was even brighter than that of the dead.
...If you mean sorrow, anger and hatred, then you're right, witch.
attributes.name: Decrepit Old Man

attributes.content: The Victorians taxed me in coin, while you and your ilk taxed me in blood. Together, you've taken all I have.
attributes.name: Decrepit Old Man

attributes.content: I've been empty inside for a while now. The only thing keeping me standing are those so-called flames of yours.
attributes.name: Decrepit Old Man

attributes.content: Then what if I were to take them back? What would you say to that?
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: I'd say 'you're late.'
attributes.name: Decrepit Old Man

attributes.content: The old man closes his eyes, facing the point of the red dragon's spear.
He can feel the fires of anger and sorrow propping him up burble as they flow into her hand. As they leave his body, his muddled consciousness leaves with them.
He can sense that death is near, but considering how stagnant his life has become, he no longer fears it.
But the fires suddenly stop flowing.
Why? Why won't you kill me?
attributes.name: Decrepit Old Man

attributes.content: Because you no longer need to be killed.
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: A spirit once told me that life will never again grace those tainted by the flames of death. Now I see that he was right.
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.content: 'Now I see that he was right,' the red dragon answered coldly.
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: How is that for an ending? I took what I heard from the old man and added a bit of spice. It shouldn't be too jarring an addition to your story, I would think.
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: Throwing in the ghost of the legendary Exiled King, are we?
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: It'll do, but do you really need the ending to my story at this point?
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: What you've seen clearly differs from what I saw. I must see it through your eyes, hear it through your ears.
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: You're not one of those bored toffs who's into 'piecing together the truth', are you?
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: I have never once considered the truth boring.
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: Hah. Well, seeing as we both managed to make it out of that hellhole alive, I can pass you all the drafts I abandoned in the process of observing, thinking and writing.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: But as for how those stories actually end, I couldn't say.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: Since you were talking about the Red Dragon... how about I start there, too?
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: The writer pours another half-mug of beer directly into his belly, glances at the woman with a hint of provocation, then begins to tell his tale.
If you have ever made the journey to the Red Dragon's Lair we call Na Saoirsí, no matter how briefly, you will never forget the Dark Woods along the way.
They are dismal and damp, filled with a gloomy mist and fae who love playing tricks on men. A labyrinth of darkest black.
It is said that, of all the people who have entered, not a one has ever left without the forest's permission.
Even if it does open its boughs to allow you passage, the mischievous fae will still lead you astray, jeering at your clumsy movements all the while. But once they finally leave you be...
It will become as beautiful as a painting, a painting that should not exist in this realm.
The red dragon, along with the people who have followed her all this way, step into the lair without the slightest hesitation, leaving that beautiful sight behind them.
Na Saoirsí, the heart of Tara, 'the Red Dragon's Lair'...
attributes.name: The Red Dragon

attributes.text: Guess you really do enjoy piecing together the truth. You must be thinking I think you don't know a damn thing, so I'm trying to mislead you?
Well, since you're already so well-informed, no need for me to beat around the bush.

attributes.content: Na Saoirsí, the heart of Tara, 'the Red Dragon's Lair'... We're finally here.
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: Thank heavens! The whole trip from the Scáthanna Fields has felt like one long, long dream... Will my family really be safe here?
attributes.name: Taran Refugee

attributes.content: This land is more than just idyllic pastures and fields.
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: Tara's capital was never directly involved in Londinium's war, but there's been a never-ending spate of infiltrations and noble rebellions going on in the background around Na Saoirsí.
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: Especially after the Red Dragon marched her troops towards Londinium... It wouldn't be incorrect to say a minor war took place here.
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: Sorry, Reed. I was just happy as can be, didn't mean anything else by it!
attributes.name: Taran Refugee

attributes.content: No... a homecoming should be a happy affair.
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: Know any songs about the city or the Dark Woods, Moran?
attributes.name: Taran Refugee

attributes.content: Only the one, and it doesn't really fit the mood...
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: Oh, just sing it!
attributes.name: Taran Refugee

attributes.content: I stepped into the dark woods one morn, calling to the mists of hoar♪
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: I trod upon the road, heading out to war♪
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: No pipes a-singing, nor battle drums a-roar♪
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: Only the bells behind me, through dew and fog their rings do soar♪
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: This whole way back, I've been trying to come up with a new verse to add, but I've been lacking inspiration.
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: You seem even more anxious than before, Reed. Was the tune really that much of a downer?
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: No, it's nothing to do with the song. It's a good song.
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: I just...
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: Loughshinny does not finish her sentence.
Behind her, the refugees step out of the forest, one after the other.
Compared to the display of leaping colors they just emerged from, Na Saoirsí seems stiff and dour. However, aside from Loughshinny, nobody minds.
All they know is they have finally ended their long sojourn. They have reached journey's end.
They have returned home.
So, what next?
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: Someone will be coming to help us. Once they're here—
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: Loughshinny spots a figure slowly walking over from the city.
It must be the man here to greet them, but the last time they met, he had wanted to kill her.
She subconsciously puts her arms out to shield Moran at her side.
...Why are you here?
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: I have come to welcome you.
attributes.name: 'The Brigadier'

attributes.content: What?
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: I'll be escorting you into Na Saoirsí to meet with Her Highness Eblana.
attributes.name: 'The Brigadier'

attributes.content: Don't worry, you'll never have to see me again. Not unless absolutely necessary.
attributes.name: 'The Brigadier'

attributes.content: Indeed. The issues we could resolve without meeting, she and I already resolved on the Gastrell.
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: Then please, follow me. As for your entourage... Due to security concerns, I will make other arrangements for them.
attributes.name: 'The Brigadier'

attributes.content: No. They are Tarans, too. They must enter with me. I promised them.
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: While I would love to acquiesce, truth be told, the majority of our citizens are unaware that there is a second red dragon. Namely, you.
attributes.name: 'The Brigadier'

attributes.content: I can guarantee that they will keep it secret.
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: This is where you and Her Highness disagree.
attributes.name: 'The Brigadier'

attributes.content: Then do you mean to say that my sister will 'ensure' they do?
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: This is precisely why I must bring them into Na Saoirsí.
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: Err... I may have an idea that would satisfy both parties, if you'd care to hear it?
I brought you here, Wakewoman, not simply as an overseer for settling citizens, but also for your discretion in sensitive matters.
attributes.name: 'The Brigadier'

attributes.content: I hope this idea of yours isn't mere wishful thinking. If so, know that even you will no longer be welcome in Na Saoirsí.
attributes.name: 'The Brigadier'

attributes.content: Of course, of course.
attributes.name: The Wakewoman

attributes.content: As you so eloquently put it, Na Saoirsí is indeed unable to so readily open its gates to our errant countrymen.
attributes.name: The Wakewoman

attributes.content: But I'm headed to the village of the wakemen tomorrow to ask for some sacred instruments. Seeing how these people have nowhere else to go, I can have them stay at the village for now.
attributes.name: The Wakewoman

attributes.content: 'Wakemen'? Isn't that some sort of codename plucked straight from the old legends?
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: My people have been relegated to song and story for many, many years, true. Those of us who live around the ruins rarely ever leave. I'm just an oddball.
attributes.name: The Wakewoman
The Wakewoman
attributes.content: Which is why I can promise you that...

attributes.name: The Wakewoman
attributes.content: well, no word of the red dragon will leave the village.
I really want to trust you, but...
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: Are you really one of them? The wakemen?
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: Moran?
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: Before my great-grandma passed, she asked for a traditional burial held by a wakeman. Our family searched all over as best we could, but never found one. All we could do was pass it off as the ramblings of a dying woman.
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: But she was a woman with her head on straight, not the type to mix things up with legends. If she said something's real, it's as real as can be. Besides, I've heard many stories about your kind.
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: I'm willing to trust you.
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: Then please don't betray that trust, Wakewoman.
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: Naturally.
attributes.name: The Wakewoman

attributes.content: ...Alright.
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: What say you, Mr. Brigadier?
attributes.name: The Wakewoman

attributes.content: Go.
attributes.name: 'The Brigadier'

attributes.content: Nemos? Who are these people?
attributes.name: Solemn Wakewoman

attributes.content: Sorry for making trouble for you even after I left.
attributes.name: The Wakewoman

attributes.content: They're Tarans with no place to call home. Na Saoirsí can't take them in at the moment, so I thought, maybe...
attributes.name: The Wakewoman

attributes.content: We made an exception many years ago by not forbidding you from leaving. We have even less reason to admit these strangers we know nothing about.
attributes.name: Solemn Wakewoman

attributes.content: What if we're not here to be admitted to the wakemen, ma'am?
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: Moran?
attributes.name: The Wakewoman

attributes.content: Once, when I still dreamt of being a wandering bard, I collected the legends of the wakemen, sought out your people, and told your tales.
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: But in the end, my dreams of both bardhood and wakemen were shattered to pieces. Only now, when all I want is to go home, do I run into you.
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: If the legends are true, your people live ascetic lives. You only come into contact with outsiders to hold funerals, letting the souls of the departed find rest in fire.
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: ...Correct.
attributes.name: Solemn Wakewoman

attributes.content: We came here with... No, we're just folks from all across Tara seeking refuge. Not a one of us is qualified to join you. We're just looking for a place to stay for a day or two.
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: I promise you, we'll follow your laws and customs as best we can. We won't trouble you any more than we already have.
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: Winter's just around the corner, too. I'm not too sure if your people hold harvest festivals, but if you need any help, please, feel free to ask.
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: ...Samhain. That is the true name of what you call the 'harvest festival'.
attributes.name: Solemn Wakewoman

attributes.content: It would seem you really are different from the cityfolk.
attributes.name: Solemn Wakewoman

attributes.content: There are some abandoned huts outside the ruins. You may clean them and stay there.
attributes.name: Solemn Wakewoman

attributes.content: Thank you. Or rather, 'go raibh maith agat.'
attributes.name: Moran

attributes.content: Is there anything else, Nemos?
attributes.name: Solemn Wakewoman

attributes.content: The Dublinners in the city want to hold a victory party to celebrate Tara's liberation.
attributes.name: The Wakewoman

attributes.content: I promised them I'd ask you for some of the sacred instruments. They'd show Taran unity, and represent the importance of tradition to the nation.
attributes.name: The Wakewoman

attributes.content: With Samhain almost upon us, we have none to spare. Have you forgotten? But even if we did, we would not give them away.
attributes.name: Solemn Wakewoman

attributes.content: They're only requesting them because of how much they value the old ways...
attributes.name: The Wakewoman

attributes.content: Then why is it that not a single denizen of Na Saoirsí has come to us to request a funeral since the city became independent?
attributes.name: Solemn Wakewoman

attributes.content: We can tell the difference between remembering a name once forgotten, and dressing yourself up in a name you've read in a history book.
attributes.name: Solemn Wakewoman

attributes.content: But if you cannot return empty-handed, then take this whistle and go.
attributes.name: Solemn Wakewoman

attributes.content: This is... just an ordinary whistle...
attributes.name: The Wakewoman

attributes.content: It is the highest honor we can give them.
attributes.name: Solemn Wakewoman

attributes.content: The wakemen do not stand with the living, nor do we require their reverence. Until, of course, they are dead.
attributes.name: Solemn Wakewoman

attributes.content: That is the tradition Dublinn should be honoring.
attributes.name: Solemn Wakewoman
